messages.msgSnippet: Ron et al - I have to say that I too have heard that the male-female post was a residual from the original decorated mekugi head . In the late-Edo when they
messages.messageBody:
Ron et al -
I have to say that I too have heard that the male-female post was a
residual from the original "decorated mekugi head". In the late-Edo
when they started reproducing old koshirae styles this type of mekugi
was seen again but most often with a screw in feature.
The section on secret marks is nothing of the sort. As I understand
it, it is a detailed explanation of the chisel work seen in
individual artists. It shows close ups of fine detail on toes,
feathers, scales and claws, showing how some of the masters put the
finishing touches on their work. If these marks are present and done
in a certain way you have evidence that it may be the work of a
certain master. If they are not present then maybe you do not. They
are all visible however, not hidden in any way, one just has to
recognize the workmanship.
and before anybody asks, I haven't done more than browse thru it, I
don't want to translate it and I don't know any secrets...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Posts
messages.msgSnippet: Hi - Honestly, I could never get too excited about the premise that menuki posts were ever made to serve as mekugi except for what you wrote, Barry, about
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

Honestly, I could never get too excited about the premise that menuki posts were ever made to serve as mekugi except for what you wrote, Barry, about early, early tsuba being rivited with the heads decorated possibly being forerunners of menuki as we know them today. But of course, I have no "other" explanation for the "male/female" posts. I do find it interesting to note that the "primary" menuki usually has the "male/solid" post whereas the "secondary" menuki has the "female/hollow" post. (Primary one would be fitted to the omote/outside of the tsuka; the secondary would be on the ura side.) Make one wonder if perhaps there is some "other" meaning behind the use of male/female menuki posts.

As for the "secret marks" of Goto, I'm not positive but it seems Jim Gilbert remarked about this section of the book awhile back, saying -- something like -- the idea of secret marks is not exactly true. Hope I'm not saying this incorrectly, but something like that. I too, have always wondered about that section of the book in hopes of "learning the key to identifying Goto works! Maybe that section just presents this idea in an overly simplified, general way?

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, May 27, 2006 8:00 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Posts


Blokes,

The story I remember is that menuki are vestigial ornaments from pre-Heian times
when the tsuka was fixed to the nakago with a rivet that was not removable. The
heads of the rivet were decorated and eventually became the menuki we know
today. What I did not know until these emails is that some menuki have
"interlocking pins" to become mekugi. Sure, I've seen these on cheap Meiji
pieces, especially tanto, but didn't know early Goto menuki had the same
feature. We can clearly see that as the Nihonto developed from earliest times
the disadvantage of a fixed rivet became evident, but the early menuki discussed
appear to have still functioned as a mekugi, only later becoming separate with a
bamboo mekugi, or mekugi of other material (iron??). I also remember that in
the Momoyama period a single menuki was used, accounting for some of the
"orphans" we see. Looking back over my collecting career I think I once had a
single (i.e., never a pair) shakudo menuki of a pomegranate. It was of that
really dark black shakudo. Sometimes knowledge comes too late to save us from
ourselves!!!

Ken, I do have somewhere a late 19th century English treatise on the Goto
mainline (Shirobei 17 generations) with photos, but it doesn't go into the
"secret marks"... Does anyone know the title of the Japanese one that Ken
mentions??

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Kenneth Wilson" <kdw21620@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, May 28, 2006 12:34 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Posts


Yes, I believe that at one point the menuki where
"interlocking" with each other, at least on some

what I had read about it, but I think this was the

roles. ok I took a stab at it, now someone can
correct what I said. Would love an english
translation of the 17 generations of goto (can't
remember japanese tittle) in which all the secret
marks are revealed.
Ken

messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, Having the book and seeing all the text with diagrams pointing to marks on a menuki, makes me almost crazy in not being able to read what they are
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,
Having the book and seeing all the text with diagrams
pointing to marks on a menuki, makes me almost crazy
in not being able to read what they are saying. Of
course, not crazy enough to actually learn japanese
like some you do.

FYI for those that want to know about the book some
more, the first section is all pics of the 17
generations work. then it gets into text what I
assume is detailing a bit about each generation and
how you can tell it was them. Has diagrams and you can
tell some things like one generation used a rounded
edge etc,. I would push for a translation more if I
really was collecting Goto work. But since I don't
collect in that range usually ($$$$$$), there are so
many other books I want info on. Of course I did
acquire 1 nice Goto mantis piece recently (most likely
Kaga Goto). Haven't seen a Mantis Goto menuki yet.
Some beautiful work though, amazing detail.

Then of course there are all the side groups who
worked in similiar style and at times did more
interesting work as the Goto school was very rigid in
what they did (ok I read that in one of those books
out there). Does anyone know of any articles on Kaga
goto? I know there is the Kaga takain, but at around
$700- 800, I'm not in the market for it. Gotta go the
"hidden fortress" is on IFC- great samurai movie.

Ken aka "the mantis dude"

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Posts
messages.msgSnippet: Blokes, The story I remember is that menuki are vestigial ornaments from pre-Heian times when the tsuka was fixed to the nakago with a rivet that was not
messages.messageBody:
Blokes,

The story I remember is that menuki are vestigial ornaments from pre-Heian times
when the tsuka was fixed to the nakago with a rivet that was not removable. The
heads of the rivet were decorated and eventually became the menuki we know
today. What I did not know until these emails is that some menuki have
"interlocking pins" to become mekugi. Sure, I've seen these on cheap Meiji
pieces, especially tanto, but didn't know early Goto menuki had the same
feature. We can clearly see that as the Nihonto developed from earliest times
the disadvantage of a fixed rivet became evident, but the early menuki discussed
appear to have still functioned as a mekugi, only later becoming separate with a
bamboo mekugi, or mekugi of other material (iron??). I also remember that in
the Momoyama period a single menuki was used, accounting for some of the
"orphans" we see. Looking back over my collecting career I think I once had a
single (i.e., never a pair) shakudo menuki of a pomegranate. It was of that
really dark black shakudo. Sometimes knowledge comes too late to save us from
ourselves!!!

Ken, I do have somewhere a late 19th century English treatise on the Goto
mainline (Shirobei 17 generations) with photos, but it doesn't go into the
"secret marks"... Does anyone know the title of the Japanese one that Ken
mentions??

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Kenneth Wilson" <kdw21620@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, May 28, 2006 12:34 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Posts


Yes, I believe that at one point the menuki where
"interlocking" with each other, at least on some
styles of sword mounting design. I can't remember
what I had read about it, but I think this was the
combo of the mekugi-ana and the menuki, but overtime
the menuki and peg seperated and served different
roles. ok I took a stab at it, now someone can
correct what I said. Would love an english
translation of the 17 generations of goto (can't
remember japanese tittle) in which all the secret
marks are revealed.
Ken

messages.subject: Menuki Posts
messages.msgSnippet: Hello all.  I am doing some research into Goto School and I noticed that on early menuki often the posts are different -- one is open ended and the other
messages.messageBody:
Hello all. I am doing some research into Goto School and I noticed
that on early menuki often the posts are different -- one is open ended
and the other closed over. Does anyone know the reason for this? I am
wondering if they were actually used for mekugi and the one projection
has been shortened having interlocked with the other originally.
Thanks much!
